A lightbulb just turned on in my head, and I can actually understand why you might _not_ want this.

In the case that the user double-clicks (by mistake) and closes the alert immediately after having opened it, they will trigger whatever action the alert entails (the callback), without having read the warning/explanation/consequences that may have been mentioned in the alert.

The way things are right now ‚Äì nothing happens on the misclick, other than the alert closing ‚Äì the user will have to click the action button again (that opens the alert) and will hopefully that time not misclick and read the message.

**Current solution**: Smart (or coincidental?) UI/UX that handles misclicks, and ensures the user has always had the chance of reading the information carried in the sweetAlert.  
**This PR**: Makes things easier for testing, and easier for developers to understand. However it may be slightly worse UI/UX as users will never see the alert (and the information in it) when misclicking.  
**Third solution**: Only handle misclicks for Confirm-alerts, where the user can actually take a "wrong" action by misclicking.

## Close

You can close the current swal through the UI or programatically using `swalService.close()`.  It will close the current swal and open the next swal after a brief (400ms) delay for the animation of closing to finish. Because the swalService's swal method returns a unique id handle, you can close specific swals (not just the current one) by using `swalService.close(swalHandleId)` even if the swal to target is pending. This is also useful if you have a swal that you don't want the user to close like an indication of loading/pending that doesn't have a close button yet the developer can close it programatically.

I'm averse to the idea of introducing a special `div` in your code that defines the contents of your sweetalert in your HTML. Among other things, it'll: - Mix style and control flow, which should be entirely separate. If I'm using Javascript, I should be able to accomplish what I want _in Javascript_. SweetAlert's main draw is that, at the moment, it functions like a pure JS solution - mixing with HTML is to me an ugly way to proceed, and detracts from its appeal. - Requires a lot of manual effort. If I have a lot of SweetAlert messages, that's a lot of cruft code I'll have to write manually or generate somehow - neither of which make for clean injections. In my opinion, a much better solution would be to do it like React.js does: allow user-defined **types** and **templates** in Javascript for the SweetAlert message. You already have support for types, except that they are very limited - you have `input`,`success`,`error` and `warning`, each of which has its own look and feel. Here, each user-defined type would let you employ a template - HTML/CSS snippets with some blank or filler spaces you can fill in using a JS object. As a rough example of how it might work, the new types and templates might do a number of things: - Let you define _keys_ that correspond to certain values in your template. e.g. if we have a template defined by ``, then one could do `swal('title': 'Hello', type='user-defined', input_type = 'file')` and have the SweetAlert render with an input box configured to accept files in place of text, with all other customisations intact. (This is also a great way to avoid XSS attacks, since you can't arbitrarily inject HTML anymore!) - Let you define how to _handle_ your input. For instance, in the context of this issue, a user could specify that all text be handled as `
{this.text}

You could define a template for the title, a template for buttons, etc. - Let you define different _actions_ e.g. instead of just slide-up or slide-down, somebody could define their own action/transition for the SweetAlert. The bottom line is that you can achieve a pure JS solution with support against XSS and more powerful customisation tools without resorting to HTML and additional data attributes as a crutch. We could recommend/use a [client-side templating engine](http://garann.github.io/template-chooser/) to structure it all. I personally favour React.js because it supports type validation out of the box when you pass in properties to a component, but of course anything else could work. 

I think the only problem with this solution might be that this would require a significant rewrite. Specifically, `sweetalert-dev.js` has a `switch` statement with an object case that simply updates the default params, rather than let you define your own. Like @t4t5 mentions, there is only one SweetAlert box that keeps getting updated each time. We need a way to 'subclass' objects - to have a base `SweetAlert` object that simply checks the `type` argument supplied, and then calls the template involved. 

One way to do this - and the one I think would be most painless, given how extensive SweetAlert is - would be to have a function called `registerTemplate()`, which registers a template in a store accessible to `swal`. `swal` would then check the `type` argument on being invoked against an internal list -`success`,`input`,`error`,`warning` - and, if not found, default to passing all other arguments to the template and somehow render it. I think `_sweetAlertInitialize$getModal$getOverlay$getInput$setFocusStyle$openModal$resetInput$fixVerticalPosition` might be able to handle the rendering, although I'd have to take a closer look at it, I'm not sure.

`targetedConfirm    = (target.className.indexOf("confirm") !=-1),`
This way, it checks that `confirm` is present in the class list.
